awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Enabling Better Grid-Scale Energy Storage with Organic Additives
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will be to provide a more economical, scalable, and sustainable type of battery for storing the energy needed to support America’s growing renewable power grid. As more wind and solar power generation is being installed, there is a growing need for economical forms of energy storage to supply power during windless and sunless times. Older technologies like lithium ion and lead acid batteries are not ideal for this purpose due to problems with supply, safety, longevity, and sustainability. This project seeks to produce new chemical components to enable grid-scale batteries based on recyclable zinc metal, which offers a safer and more sustainable alternative grid-scale battery option. Furthermore, since zinc and its other battery components are sourced in the US, this project may help facilitate domestic battery manufacturing and reduce dependence on foreign battery supplies.

This SBIR Phase II project proposes to produce chemical additives that make zinc-bromine batteries last longer, hold more energy, and run more efficiently so that they can provide sustainable low-cost energy storage for renewable power. Presently, the major problems with these types of batteries are related to unwanted electrochemical side reactions that happen during battery charging. This project will eliminate these side reactions with stable, scalable, organic electrolyte additives designed to prevent problems at the zinc surface.  During this phase of the project, these electrolyte addititives will be modified and optimized for performance and scalability. They will be evaluated via testing in actual cells and full-size batteries by the battery manufacturers. By the end of the project, new class of enabling electrolyte may be available in large quantities to help establish safe, sustainable, domestically made zinc-bromine batteries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The outcome of this NSF SBIR Phase 2 project is a family of new battery electrolyte chemicals that can be used to increase the capacity of zinc-based grid-scale batteries by up to 25%. These new chemicals work by allowing more of the zinc metal inside to be utilized for energy storage. This will have a significant impact on the future of US energy since the zinc batteries it empowers are safer, longer-lasting, US-made, and more sustainable than lithium-based alternatives. The US is one of the largest producers of zinc in the world and zinc is already recycled widely in the US. Also, zinc batteries are water-based so they are nonflammable, and zinc is not a hazard to human health. Thanks to the work of this SBIR Phase 2 project, these batteries will be a future-proof solution to support sustainable energy and a smarter, more reliable domestic American power grid.

Zinc batteries are emerging as a better choice for large scale energy storage but to compete with incumbent lithium technologies they need near-term optimization with better internal chemicals. For many reasons, zinc batteries are a better option on the grid. Zinc is abundant, widely recycled, and highly available in the US. Zinc batteries are water-based, nonflammable, temperature tolerant and based on low-hazards materials. However, zinc batteries have lower capacities than lithium-ion batteries and are far behind lithium in their development. Despite being a better long-term option, zinc batteries need immediate improvement to compete today and become established on the grid so that the US can enjoy a century of safe, sustainable, US-made energy storage.

To accelerate the emergence of zinc batteries to support long-term US energy sustainability and independence, this NSF SBIR Phase 2 project led to the creation of optimized electrolyte chemicals to dramatically improve zinc battery capacity. Zinc batteries store energy by converting zinc compounds like zinc bromide or zinc oxide (the drained state) into pure zinc metal (the charged state). The amount of charge the battery can hold is limited to the amount of zinc compounds that can be converted to zinc metal. Due to physical constraints, not all of the zinc compounds can be converted to metal before this process becomes too inefficient to continue. Now, the chemical products created by this NSF SBIR Phase 2 project can allow the battery to efficiently convert more zinc compounds into zinc metal, thereby allowing the batteries to charge up to 25% more. This is a significant improvement to zinc battery capacity, and it will help to create a safe, reliable, sustainable, and domestically-made US energy grid.

 


Last Modified: 08/26/2024
Modified by: Onas J Bolton
